titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Lorenz Reich Letters
1870-1912
MS 517
titlestmt.author: Elise Winks

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-25 10:01:53 -0400.

did.abstract:
Collection of letters received by Lorenz Reich in praise of his wine, from physicians, jurists, statesmen, and men of letters, including: Robert Browning, Samuel L. Clemens, Walt Whitman, John Greenleaf Whittier, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Grover Cleveland, U.S. Grant, David Dudley Field, Oliver Wendell Holmes. Reich was an importer of Hungarian wine and proprietor of Cambridge Hotel, New York City.
To request this material for research, and for fuller information about it, please follow this link to the record in N-YHS's catalog, Bobcat: Lorenz Reich letters received
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to 20 exposures of stable, unbound material per day.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as: Lorenz Reich letters, MS 517, New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lorenz Reich was born in Hungary and as a young man moved to the United States, where he garnered a reputation as a builder and an importer of Hungarian wine. In 1887 Reich opened the Cambridge Hotel, located on 33rd Street and 5th Avenue in Manhattan, and was its proprieter for many years. He was involved in a 24-year lawsuit over the property with William F. Cochran, before an eventual verdict in Reich's favor in 1915.
Reich was perhaps most well-known for importing his Ausbruch Tokay wine, which was favored by many prominent members of society as well as touted as a medicinal remedy by many physicians.
Reich had six children with his wife, Elizabeth, and died in New York in 1931, at the age of 82.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection is not processed. As part of a project conducted in 2019-20, archivist Elise Winks performed a high level survey of the collection and described it broadly in this preliminary finding aid.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in two series:
Series I. Prominent Figures (A list of correspondents is shown for this series)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TBD

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters Reich received in praise of his wine from well-known figures in various fields. Includes those prominent in the fields of literature, theater, science, finance, politics, military, and the law. Arranged alphabetically by sender's surname, with one folder for each sender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence sent by the English poet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from the United States president

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from British novelist Amelia Edith Huddleston Barr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from lawyer and politician Perry Belmont.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Frank S. Black, governor of New York from 1897 to 1898.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters and a signed photograph to Reich from English poet Robert Browning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Mary Baird Bryan, wife of politician and presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to Reich from writer Oliver Bell Bunce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Associate Justice of the Supreme Court Benjamin Cardozo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to Reich from writer Julius Chambers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from famed American author Samuel R. Clemens, also known as Mark Twain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Grover Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three letters from J.D. Coleridge, Lord Chief Justice of England from 1880 to 1894.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to Reich from Senator Roscoe Conkling., United States senator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from railroad entrepreneur Austin Corbin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Richard Croker, Tammany Hall boss from 1886 to 1902.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Napoleon Daru, French soldier and politician.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Charles Deems, pastor of Church of the Strangers on Mercer Street in Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Chauncey Depew, New York senator, lawyer, and railroad executive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from chemist Robert Ogden Doremus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Senator William M. Evarts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from John Murphy Farley, Archbishop of New York from 1902 to 1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters Correspondence from Cyrus West Field, businessman and promoter of the first Atlantic cable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from businessman John H. Flagler, who owned a tube works and wrought iron pipe firm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three letters from First Lady Lucretia Garfield, wife of James A. Garfield, 20th President of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from William Ewart Gladstone, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1868 to 1894.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Robert Goelet, a New York City real estate owner, financier, and businessman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Frederick Dent Grant, New York police commissioner, United States ambassador to Austria-Hungary, and son of Ulysses S. Grant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Adolphus Washington Greely, a United States Army officer who received the Medal of Honor in 1935. Includes three letters discussing Greely's famed Arctic exploration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Hetty Green, a businesswoman and financier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from writer Marion Harland, also known as Mary Terhune. Harland wrote novels and non-fiction works on domestic topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters and a signed photograph from Hildegarde Hawthorne, writer and granddaughter of novelist Nathaniel Hawthorne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 31 letters and a signed photograph from Julian Hawthorne, writer and son of famed novelist Nathaniel Hawthorne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters from publishing magnate and politician William Randolph Hearst, written early in his career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One letter and one poem written by poet Julia M. Holmes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 16 letters and a signed photograph from writer and physician Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from journalist William Henry Hurlbert.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Henry Baldwin Hyde, businessman and founder of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from John Francis Hylan, mayor of New York City from 1918 to 1925.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three letters from British actor Henry Irving.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from George Jones, journalist and co-founder of the New York Times.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Mary Ensign Kountze, wife of prominent banker Charles B. Kountze.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five letters from Rose Hawthorne Lathrop, daughter of writer Nathaniel Hawthorne. Lathrop was a writer herself, and later became a Roman Catholic sister known as Mother Mary Alphonsa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from French writer Richard Lesclide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three letters from writer Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. One, written only two weeks before his death, is believed to be one of the last letters ever written by Longfellow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from poet James Russell Lowell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from lawyer and social leader Ward McAllister, who originatedm the phrase "The Four Hundred," referring to prominent members of society in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two lettersCorrespondence from Cardinal John McCloskey, Archbishop of New York from 1864 to 1885.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from inventor and chemist Hudson Maxim. Maxim was the inventor of several types of explosives, including smokeless gunpowder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from poet Joaquin Miller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from publisher William Penn Nixon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four letters from Frank Noyes, one of the founders of the Associated Press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 19 letters from Alton B. Parker, judge on the New York Supreme Court and Court of Appeals, and unsuccessful candidate for president against Theodore Roosevelt in 1904.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Charles Henry Parkhurst, a Presbyterian minister who exposed the corruption in New York City government, particularly in Tammany Hall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Adelina Patti, a famous Italian opera singer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from financier James W. Paul, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from mining geologist Richard Alexander Fullerton Penrose.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from abolitionist Wendell Phillips.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from poet John James Piatt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Henry Codman Potter, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Percy R. Pyne II, banker and financier, grandson of Moses Taylor, and collector of engraved plates depicting various views of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Whitelaw Reid, prominent Republican politician, including the 1892 Republican presidential candidate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Elliott Bulloch Roosevelt, brother of United States President Theodore Roosevelt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Brooklyn gangster Ernesto Rossi, associate of Frankie Yale and Al Capone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Italian actor Tommaso Salvini.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Horatio Seymour, two-time governor of New York and Democratic nominee for United States President in 1868.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Mary French Sheldon, also known as May French Sheldon, author and explorer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from General of the Army Philip Sheridan., General of the Army..

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from famed Union Army General William Tecumseh Sherman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from politician and Civil War soldier Daniel Sickles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from lawyer John Woodruff Simpson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Wisconsin politician John Coit Spooner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Welsh explorer and journalist Henry Morton Stanley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from New York governor William Sulzer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from North Carolina politician and white supremacist Benjamin Tillman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from writer Henry van Dyke, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Augustus Van Wyck, Supreme Court Justice of Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to Reich from Victoria, Queen of Great Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six letters from Quaker poet and abolitionist John G. Whittier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from Edward Shippen Willing and his wife, Alice Barton Willing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More than 1,500 letters written to Reich from physicians across the United States, mostly regarding his wine.
